awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Targeted resampling of deep polar ice cores using information theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Ice cores contain detailed accounts of Earth's climate history.  The collection of an ice core can be logistically challenging, and extraction of data from the core can be time-consuming as well as susceptible to both human and machine error.  Furthermore, locked in measurements from ice cores is information that scientists have not yet found ways to recover. This project will apply techniques from information theory to ice-core data to unlock that information. The primary goal is to demonstrate that information theory can (a) identify regions of a specific ice-core record that are in need of further analysis and (b) provide some specific guidance for that analysis. A secondary goal is to demonstrate that information theory has practical and scientific utility for studies of past climate. 

This project aims to use information theory in two distinct ways: first, to identify regions of a core where information appears to be damaged or missing, perhaps due to human and/or machine error. In the segment of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet Divide core that is 5000-8000 years old, for instance, information-theoretic methods reveal significant levels of noise, probably due to a laboratory instrument, and something that was not visible in the raw data. This is a particularly important segment of the record, as it contains valuable clues about climatic shifts and the onset of the Holocene. Targeted re-sampling of this segment of the core and reanalysis with newer laboratory apparatus could resolve the data issues. The second way in which information theory can potentially aid in ice-core analysis is by extracting climate signals from the data--such as the accumulation rate at the core site over the period of its formation.  This quantity usually requires significant time and effort to produce, but information theory could help to streamline that process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this EAGER were to demonstrate that information theory could identify regions of a specific ice core record that needs further analysis and provide some specific guidance for that analysis. A secondary, but important, motivation for this EAGER was to illustrate to the paleoscience community that information theory is not just a forensic tool and not just of theoretical interest, but rather a practical, useful way to arrive at valuable insights about the climate system.

For the first goal, we demonstrated, in a paper published in Entropy, that using weighted and unweighted permutation entropy with water-isotope records from the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) Divide Ice Core we could indeed identify anomalous regions of the data. In one region of these isotope records, our algorithm revealed an abrupt change in the complexity of the traces: specifically, in the amount of new information that appeared at every time step. See Figure 1, where there is a clear increase in complexity from approximately 2,340 - 6,000 years before present. We conjectured that this effect was due to noise introduced by an older laboratory instrument. We validated that conjecture by remeasuring 331m of ice using a more advanced version of the laboratory instrument. The anomalous noise levels were absent from the permutation entropy traces of the new data; see Figure 2.  In other sections of the core, we showed that permutation entropy techniques could be used to identify anomalies in the data that were not associated with climatic or glaciological processes, but rather effects occurring during field work, laboratory analysis, or data post-processing. These examples make it clear that permutation entropy is a useful forensic tool for identifying sections of data that require targeted reanalysis---and can even be useful for guiding that analysis.  This technique, as well as our specific guidance for using this methodology, is now being used in the standard data processing pipeline for analyzing other similar deep polar ice cores, including the South Pole Ice Core (SPICEcore) and the East Greenland Ice-Core Project (EastGRIP), to identify anomalous sections of those datasets.

The secondary motivation for this EAGER was to illustrate to the paleoscience community that information theory is a useful way to arrive at valuable insights about the climate system. In a paper published in Chaos, we demonstrated that the weighted-permutation entropy of water-isotope data from WAIS Divide Ice Core revealed meaningful climate signals in this record. We found that weighted-permutation entropy correlated with accumulation (meters of ice equivalent per year) and may record the influence of geothermal heating effects in the deepest parts of the core. Surprisingly, large climatological events such as Dansgaard-Oeschger and Antarctic Isotope Maxima events, however, did not appear to leave strong signatures in the information record, suggesting that these abrupt warming events may be predictable features of the climate's dynamics. While the potential power of information theory in paleoclimatology is significant, the associated methods require well-dated and high-resolution data. The WAIS Divide Ice Core dataset is the first paleoclimate record that can support this kind of analysis. As more high-resolution records become available, information theory may become a powerful tool in paleoclimate science.

Beyond scientific achievements, this EAGER had several broader impacts. For example, PI Garland utilized the grant to support the research projects of three undergraduates, one from an under-represented group from a tier 2 university, providing them with professional development opportunities (in addition to research experience) that were simply not accessible at their home institution. As this was PI Garland's first grant, it has allowed him the opportunity to learn the process of leading and managing a research grant. Additionally, this grant also provided collaborative funding to travel to several conferences, where the PI Garland could further develop his ideas, and build his professional network, which is crucial at this stage in his career. Finally, as a form of community outreach/dissemination, we posted a YouTube video to the Santa Fe Institute channel, which aimed to make our findings accessible to the general public.  In addition to this community outreach, we wrote a thought piece for SIAM News, a news journal of the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics which was effectively a "call-to-arms" for applied mathematicians to begin working on this exciting intersection of paleoclimate science and information theory.
